page.title: 01DERBYS. DALES & VILLAGES
page.content: {CRESSBROOK AND WARDLOW AREA} This is an area in the Peak District National Park comprised of Carbonif- erous limestone covered by rough pasture, river meadow, moorland and deciduous woods. The River Wye creates the deep dales, Upper Monsal and Cressbrook. The land rises from 235 to 391 metres on Longstone Moor and Wardlow Hay Top. The B6465 road from Wardlow, a small agricultural village, runs South to Monsal Head. Minor roads go to Cressbrook (a mill village in the Wye Valley), to Litton and Litton Mill. Fluorspar is mined, but lead workings are abandoned. Rambling, fishing,and the glorious scenery attract visitors, thus creating employment. Buildings are of local limestone. Farms with small stone walled fields support dairy cows, beef and sheep. Population is of all ages.
